newsitem.title: UK: Chartists champion gilts after fundamental fillip.
newsitem.headline: Chartists champion gilts after fundamental fillip.

text.p: As if Britain's bond market did not have enough going for it, the charts are also in its favour these days, say technical analysts.

Ignited by sweeping reforms to the Bank of England, British gilts staged their biggest one-day gain in five years on Tuesday. On Wednesday, after scrutinising charts dating back to 1986, analysts said the market had more life in it yet.
Deutsche Morgan Grenfell technical analyst Elizabeth Miller said the rally, while fundamentally inspired, was a strong signal. "Obviously it makes it pretty bullish on the charts."

June gilt futures on LIFFE at 1312 GMT were at 113-04, off 9/32 from the prior close. On Tuesday, they soared to a contract high of 113-24, more than two and a half points above the London close on Friday of 111-04.
While short-term profit-taking will probably restrain the gilt market for a while, some technical analysts see gains of around four full points from here in the longer run.
British markets, which were shut on Monday for a holiday, were greeted with the news on Tuesday that new Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown was giving the Bank of England greater independence.

The reforms, which include setting up a monetary policy committee on which the government has no vote, cheered sterling-based investors who now see politics taking a backseat to prudent interest rate policy.

Francoise Skelley, head of global trading technical analysis at Credit Suisse First Boston in London, said monthly continuation charts dating back to 1986 showed a downtrend line in place that currently came in the 117-118 area.
She told Reuters Financial Television the market was vulnerable to a pullback but that that line would act as a target on the upside.
"Short-term the market is very overbought," she said.
For Miller, the key was to get back, and stay, above 113-19, which was a former contract high which gilts took out during their blistering rally on Tuesday.
"Really it looks pretty good at the moment but it's got to sustain a break of 113-19. Gains from here are going to be a lot slower," she said.
The short-term caution that many analysts currently hold on gilts extends to the long term for some chartists.
Anne Whitby, head of technical analysis at 4CAST in London, was sceptical gilts would even get up to the 11-year-old resistance line, which she pegged at 117-12.
"I still don't think it's the beginning of something new and exciting and different," Whitby said. "I think it's a sluggish rally."
She said she could envision the market rising to the 115-00 to 116-00 area. "Beyond that I wouldn't really be looking for much."
And Skelley, who set the downtrend line target just above 117-00, added that she did expect gilts to falter up there.
